content.intro: Sample letter sent to participants with medical conditions that require modified breathwork practice.
content.letterText:
Dear Participant,

I hope this message finds you well. We are pleased to confirm your registration for the [EVENT NAME] with Dr. Joe Dispenza. Upon reviewing the information provided during your registration or medical Zoom evaluation, we have identified certain medical considerations that may require modifications to the breathwork practice during the retreat. Please review the details below carefully.

section1.title: Breathwork Contraindications
section1.content: Breathwork induces specific physiological changes in the body and may lead to significant physical and emotional release. As a precaution, the following conditions may require modifications to the breathwork exercises:
conditions: Severe post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) or other trauma
Medications that alter brain chemistry (e.g., medications for anxiety, depression, ADD, OCD)
Prescription blood thinners or anti-clotting medications
Cardiovascular disease (including angina, history of heart attack, or other cardiovascular issues)
Seizures (past or present) or other neurological conditions or diseases
Prior diagnosis of bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, or other psychiatric conditions
Recent surgery, stitches, or injury within the last six months (including laparoscopic procedures and hernias)

section2.title: Modified Breathwork Practice
section2.content:
If any of the above conditions apply to you, we recommend practicing modified, gentler versions of the breathwork exercises during the retreat. Dr. Joe will guide the full breathwork practice, and we respectfully request that if you have any of the listed conditions, you engage with the modified version to ensure your safety.

The modifications are designed to minimize actions that could increase pressure in the head or brain, such as pulling, pushing, or squeezing the abdominal or pelvic muscles. Instead, a slower, steady breath, with a focus on gently releasing air through the nose, can be practiced, with special attention to the pineal gland area. It is important to avoid squeezing, pulling up, or pushing of the perineal and abdominal muscles.

section3.title: Contact Information
section3.content:
Our support team is available to assist you throughout your journey. If you have any questions or require further clarification, please reach out to:

• Keysi Del Valle, RN, BSN - Medcare@drjoedispenza.com
• Jessica Sprague - Medsupport@drjoedispenza.com

We look forward to supporting you and ensuring you have a safe and transformative experience at the retreat.

Warm regards,
Keysi M. Del Valle, RN, BSN
Encephalon Event Medical Lead
